pgmcomponents.gui.calc_beam_size(electron_size: float, electron_div: float, wavelength: float, distance: float, length: float, num_of_sigmas=3, insertion_device='undulator') → float[source]¶

Calculate the beam size based on the electron size and divergence.

Parameters:

  • electron_size (float) – The electron size in um

  • electron_div (float) – The electron divergence in urad

  • params (wavelength not photon_energy in) –

  • photon_energy (float) – The photon energy in eV

  • distance (float) – The distance from the source to the image plane in m

  • length (float) – The length of the insertion device in m

  • num_of_sigmas (int) – The number of sigmas to use when calculating the beam size

  • insertion_device (str) – The type of insertion device, can be ‘undulator’ or ‘wiggler’, default is ‘undulator’

Returns:

The RMS photon beam size at distance in mm

Return type:

float

pgmcomponents.gui.draw_figure_w_toolbar(canvas, fig, canvas_toolbar)[source]¶

Method to draw on a given canvas and toolbar.

Parameters:

  • canvas (Canvas) – Canvas to draw on.

  • fig (Figure) – Figure to draw.

  • canvas_toolbar (Canvas) – Canvas to draw toolbar on.

class pgmcomponents.gui.EPICScontrol(name: str, value: float, increments: float, key: str, pgm=None)[source]¶

Bases: object

A EPICS like control widget.

Parameters:

  • name (str) – The name of the control.

  • value (float) – The default value of the control

  • increments (float) – The default increment value of the control.

  • key (str) – The key of the control.

  • pgm (PGM) – The PGM object.

up(window)[source]¶

Add increment to value

down(window)[source]¶

Subtract increment from value

update(window)[source]¶

Update the displayed value of the control.

write(window, value, pgm)[source]¶

Write a value to the control.

up(window: PySimpleGUI.Window, values: dict, pgm: pgmcomponents.elements.PGM) → None[source]¶
Parameters:

  • window (PySimpleGUI.Window) – The window object containing the control.

  • values (dict) – The values of the window.

  • pgm (PGM) – The PGM object.

Returns:

  • None

  • Add increment to value, needs the window object to update the value.

down(window: PySimpleGUI.Window, values: dict, pgm: pgmcomponents.elements.PGM) → None[source]¶

Subtract the increment value from the current value of the widget. If the widget is an order widget, the current value is converted to an integer before subtraction. The updated value is then set as the new value of the widget and also updated in the corresponding attribute of the pgm object.

Parameters:

  • window (PySimpleGUI.Window) – The window object containing the control.

  • values (dict) – The values of the window.

  • pgm (PGM20) – The PGM object.

update(window: PySimpleGUI.Window, pgm: pgmcomponents.elements.PGM) → None[source]¶

Update the value of the control.

Parameters:

  • window (The window object containing the control.) –

  • pgm (The program object containing the property to be updated.) –

Return type:

None

write(window: PySimpleGUI.Window, value: dict, pgm: pgmcomponents.elements.PGM) → None[source]¶

Subroutine to write the values of a known pgm to the window.

Parameters:

  • value (float) – The value to write to the control.

  • pgm (PGM) – The PGM object.

pgmcomponents.gui.configuration_popup(title: str, key: str, element: pgmcomponents.elements.Plane_Mirror | pgmcomponents.elements.Grating, window) → dict[source]¶

Creates a popup window for configuration of Plane_Mirror or Grating.

Parameters:

  • title (str) – The title of the popup window.

  • key (str) – The key of the element.

  • element (Plane_Mirror or Grating) – The element to configure. Either ‘Plane_Mirror’ or ‘Grating’.

Returns:

values – A dictionary of values for the element.

Return type:

dict

class pgmcomponents.gui.Point3D(x, y, z)[source]¶

Bases: object

A class for a simple 3D point.

Parameters:

  • x (float) – The x coordinate of the point

  • y (float) – The y coordinate of the point

  • z (float) – The z coordinate of the point

__repr__ : str

Returns a string representation of the point

__add__ : Point3D

Adds two points together

__sub__ : Point3D

Subtracts two points

__eq__ : bool

Checks if two points are equal

__ne__ : bool

Checks if two points are not equal

__getitem__ : float

Returns the x, y or z coordinate of the point

__setitem__ : float

Sets the x, y or z coordinate of the point

__iter__ : float

Returns an iterator over the point

__len__ : int

Returns the length of the point

__hash__ : int

Returns the hash of the point

__copy__ : Point3D

Returns a copy of the point

__deepcopy__ : Point3D

Returns a deep copy of the point

copy : Point3D

Returns a copy of the point

distance : float

Finds the distance between two points

class pgmcomponents.gui.Plane(*args)[source]¶

Bases: object

A class for a simple plane

Based on the work of Matthew Hand

Parameters:

*args – Either a point and a normal vector, or three points defining the plane, np.array_like

point¶

A point on the plane

Type:

array_like

normal¶

The normal vector of the plane

Type:

array_like

__repr__ : str

Returns a string representation of the plane

__eq__ : bool

Checks if two planes are equal

intersectQ : bool

Checks if the plane intersects another plane or ray3d

property point¶
property position¶
property normal¶
__repr__()[source]¶

Return repr(self).

__eq__(other)[source]¶

Return self==value.

intersectQ(other, atol=1e-06)[source]¶

Checks if the plane intersects another plane or ray3d

Parameters:

  • other (Plane or Ray3D) – The other plane or ray3d

  • atol (float) – The absolute tolerance for the dot product of the normal vectors

Returns:

  • bool – True if the plane intersects the other plane or ray3d, False otherwise

  • Point3D or None – The point of intersection if the plane intersects the other plane or ray3d, None otherwise

class pgmcomponents.gui.Plane_Mirror(voffset=13, hoffset=40, axis_voffset=6.5, axis_hoffset=0, dimensions=np.array([450, 70, 50]), theta=45, plane=Plane(), borders=np.array([0, 0, 0, 0]))[source]¶

Bases: object

A class for a simple plane mirror.

Parameters:

  • voffset (float, optional) – The vertical offset of the mirror in mm

  • hoffset (float, optional) – The horizontal offset of the mirror in mm

  • axis_voffset (float, optional) – The vertical offset of the mirror axis in mm

  • axis_hoffset (float, optional) – The horizontal offset of the mirror axis in mm

  • dimensions (array_like, optional) – The dimensions of the mirror in mm [length, width, height] Dimensions are also accessible with lambda functions as: self._length(), self._width(), self._height()

  • theta (float, optional) – The angle of the mirror in degrees

  • plane (Plane, optional) – The plane of the mirror

  • borders (array_like, optional) –

    Specifies the borders for a realistic plane mirror:

    borders : array_like Specifies the borders of a realistic grating component. |-----------Top------------| | |

    Left Mirror Plane Right
    | —> +z direction

    |----------Bottom----------| [top, bottom, left, right]

dimensions¶

The dimensions of the mirror in mm

Type:

array_like

position¶

The position of the mirror

Type:

Point3D

normal¶

The normal vector of the mirror

Type:

Vector3D

orientation¶

The orientation of the mirror

Type:

Vector3D

corners¶

The corners of the grating in the global coordinate system: [bottom left back, bottom right back, bottom left front, bottom right front, top left back, top right back, top left front, top right front]

Type:

array_like

plane¶

The plane of the mirror

Type:

Plane

borders¶

Specifies the borders for a realistic plane mirror: borders : array_like Specifies the borders of a realistic grating component. |-----------Top------------| | |

Left Mirror Plane Right
| —> +z direction

|----------Bottom----------| [top, bottom, left, right]

Type:

array_like

read_file(filename)[source]¶

Read mirror parameters from a file. See config_pgm.ini for an example. A config_file may contain more than one sections, but only the mirror section will be read.

Parameters:

filename (str) – The name of the file to read from

compute_corners() → numpy.ndarray[source]¶

Compute the corners of the mirror in the global coordinate system, in addition to the plane and normal of the mirror.

Returns:

corners – The corners of the mirror in the global coordinate system [bottom left back, bottom right back, bottom left front, bottom right front, top left back, top right back, top left front, top right front]

Return type:

np.ndarray

classmethod mirror_from_file(filename: str) → Plane_Mirror[source]¶

Create a mirror from a file. See config_pgm.ini for an example. A config_file may contain more than one sections, but only the mirror section will be read.

Parameters:

filename (str) – The name of the file to read from

class pgmcomponents.gui.Grating(line_density=600, energy=2400, cff=2, order=1, dimensions=np.array([200, 40, 50]), borders=np.array([0, 0, 0, 0]))[source]¶

Bases: object

A class for a simple grating

Based on the work of Matthew Hand

Parameters:

  • line_density (float) – The line density of the grating in lines per mm

  • energy (float) – The energy of the incident beam in eV

  • cff (float) – The fixed focus constant of the grating

  • order (int) – The diffraction order of the grating

  • dimensions (array_like) – The dimensions of the grating in mm [length, width, height], dimensions are also accessible with lambda functions as: self._length(), self._width(), self._height()

  • borders (array_like) –

    Specifies the borders of a realistic grating component.

    |-----------Top------------| | |

    Left Grating Plane Right
    | —-> +z direction

    |----------Bottom----------| [top, bottom, left, right]

    Left - Right => Tangential Top - Bottom => Sagittal

line_density¶

The line density of the grating in lines per mm

Type:

float

energy¶

The energy of the incident beam in eV

Type:

float

cff¶

The fixed focus constant of the grating

Type:

float

order¶

The diffraction order of the grating

Type:

int

alpha¶

The incident angle of the beam in degrees

Type:

float

beta¶

The diffraction angle of the beam in degrees

Type:

float

dimensions¶

The dimensions of the grating in mm

Type:

array_like

corners¶

The corners of the grating in the global coordinate system: [bottom left back, bottom right back, bottom left front, bottom right front, top left back, top right back, top left front, top right front]

Type:

array_like

borders¶

Specifies the borders of a realistic grating component. |-----------Top------------| | |

Left Grating Plane Right
| —-> +z direction

|----------Bottom----------| [top, bottom, left, right]

Left - Right => Tangential Top - Bottom => Sagittal

Type:

array_like

set_angles(alpha, beta)[source]¶

Set the incident and diffraction angles of the grating

Compute the corners of the grating in the global coordinate system

read_file(filename)[source]¶

Read grating parameters from a file. See config_pgm.ini for an example. A config_file may contain more than one sections, but only the grating section will be read.

Parameters:

filename (str) – The name of the file to read from

set_angles(alpha: float, beta: float) → None[source]¶

Set the incident and diffraction angles of the grating.

Parameters:

  • alpha (float) – The incident angle in degrees

  • beta (float) – The diffraction angle in degrees

Raises:

ValueError – If the wavelength is zero

compute_beta() → float[source]¶

Compute the diffraction angle beta from the incident angle alpha.

Returns:

beta – The diffraction angle in degrees

Return type:

float

compute_angles() → tuple[float, float][source]¶

Compute the incident and diffraction angles of the grating. The incident angle is calculated from the diffraction angle using the fixed focus constant.

Returns:

  • alpha (float) – The incident angle in degrees

  • beta (float) – The diffraction angle in degrees

diffract(*args: pgmcomponents.geometry.Ray3D | list) → list[source]¶

A method to diffract rays off the grating.

Parameters:

*args (Ray3D or list of Ray3D) – The rays to be diffracted

Returns:

diffracted_rays – A list of diffracted rays

Return type:

list of Ray3D

Raises:

  • raises ValueError too –

  • TypeError – If the rays are not Ray3D objects

compute_corners() → numpy.ndarray[source]¶

Compute the corners of the grating in the global coordinate system.

corners – The corners of the grating in the global coordinate system: [bottom left back, bottom right back, bottom left front, bottom right front, top left back, top right back, top left front, top right front]

Return type:

array_like

classmethod grating_from_file(filename)[source]¶

Create a grating from a file. See config_pgm.ini for an example. A config_file may contain more than one sections, but only the grating section will be read.

class pgmcomponents.gui.PGM(grating=None, mirror=None, **kwargs)[source]¶

Bases: object

A class for a PGM setup.

Parameters:

  • grating (Grating) – The grating component of the PGM

  • mirror (Plane_Mirror) – The mirror component of the PGM

grating¶

The grating component of the PGM

Type:

Grating

mirror¶

The mirror component of the PGM

Type:

Plane_Mirror

rays¶

The rays to be propagated through the PGM

Type:

list

beam_offset¶

The vertical offset of the beam in mm

Type:

float

beam_width¶

The width of the beam in mm

Type:

float

beam_height¶

The height of the beam in mm

Type:

float

read_file(filename)[source]¶

Read PGM parameters from a file. See config_pgm.ini for an example. The config file should contain a grating and a mirror section.

propagate(*args)[source]¶

Propagate rays through the PGM setup.

draw_sideview(ax)[source]¶

Draws the setup on a y-z projection on a given axis.

draw_topview(ax)[source]¶

Draws the setup on a x-z projection on a given axis, along with the beam footprints.

generate_rays()[source]¶

Generate rays for the PGM setup.

read_file(filename)[source]¶

Read PGM parameters from a file. See config_pgm.ini for an example. The config file should contain a grating and a mirror section.

Parameters:

filename (str) – The name of the file to read from

set_theta()[source]¶

Set the angle of the grating.

values() → dict[source]¶
classmethod pgm_from_file(filename: float) → PGM[source]¶

Create a PGM from a file. See config_pgm.ini for an example. The config file should contain a grating and a mirror section.

Parameters:

filename (str) – The name of the file to read from

propagate(*args: pgmcomponents.geometry.Ray3D | list) → tuple[source]¶

Propagate rays through the PGM setup.

Parameters:

*args (Ray3D) – The rays to be propagated

Returns:

  • grating_ray (list of Ray3D objects) – A list of propagated rays originating at the grating intercept

  • mirror_intercept (list of array_like) – A list of the mirror intercepts

  • grating_intercept (list of array_like) – A list of the grating intercepts

draw_topview(ax: matplotlib.axes.Axes) → None[source]¶

Draws the top-view (x-z projection) of the setup on the current axes.

Draws the top-view (x-z projection) of the setup on the current axes.

calc_footprint_size(intercepts: list[pgmcomponents.geometry.Point3D]) → tuple[source]¶

Calculate the size of the footprint of the beam on the grating or the mirror when given the intercepts of the beam with the grating or the mirror.

Parameters:

intercepts (list of Point3D objects) – The intercepts of the beam with the grating or the mirror [r_1, r_2, r_3, r_4]

Returns:

size – The size of the footprint of the beam on the grating or the mirror in mm

Return type:

tuple

corners() → tuple[dict][source]¶

Calculate the corners of the mirror and grating.

Returns:

corners – The corners of the grating and mirror in the following order: bottom left back, bottom right back, bottom left front, bottom right front, top left back, top right back, top left front, top right front

dict

pgmcomponents.gui.draw_figure_w_toolbar(canvas, fig, canvas_toolbar)[source]¶

Method to draw on a given canvas and toolbar.

Parameters:

  • canvas (Canvas) – Canvas to draw on.

  • fig (Figure) – Figure to draw.

class pgmcomponents.gui.Toolbar(*args, **kwargs)[source]¶

Bases: matplotlib.backends.backend_tkagg.NavigationToolbar2Tk

canvas¶

The figure canvas on which to operate.

Type:

FigureCanvas

win¶

The tk.Window which owns this toolbar.

Type:

tk.Window

pack_toolbar¶

If True, add the toolbar to the parent’s pack manager’s packing list during initialization with side='bottom' and fill='x'. If you want to use the toolbar with a different layout manager, use pack_toolbar=False.

Type:

bool, default: True
